Peter,

Given an arbitrary point "P" in design space, comprised of the=3D20=

following:
(a) problem specific inputs (PSIs);
(b) auxiliary additional pa=
rameters associated w/ PSIs;
(c) problem specific outputs (PSOs);
(d) auxil=
iary additional parameters associated w/ PSOs;

Substrate Inputs: comprised=
 of PSIs, "a" above; Substrate Outputs: 
comprised of PSOs, "c" above;

Hyp=
ercube Inputs: comprised of auxiliary additional parameters=3D20 
associate=
d w/ PSIs & PSOs, "b" & "d" above; Hypercube Output: weight 
between curren=
t pair of substrate nodes

If:
(1) the dimensionality of the hypercube inpu=
t "from" node is=3D20 
different in number and/or nature as the links in th=
e substrate=3D20 
network are looped over, or
(2)  the dimensionality of th=
e hypercube input "to" node is 
different=3D20 in number and/or nature as t=
he links in the substrate 
network are=3D20 looped over,

...then the topol=
ogy of the hypercube inputs are different/change 
as=3D20 you loop over the=
 substrate links, while computing the current 
link=3D20 weight with the hy=
percube network.

   The examples and explanations provided to date do not =
address 
this=3D20 more general condition.

   Does this explain the issue =
in question better?

Thanks,
   Andy Carl


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "p=
etar_chervenski" 
<petar_chervenski@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Andy, 
> 
> I am sor=
ry, but I didn't understand what you mean by "hypercube 
input 
> topology"=
? 
> As far as I know, this is simply a CPPN taking 2 points from the 
> su=
bstrate space (connective CPPN) instead of only one (spatial 
CPPN). 
> The=
 coordinates of this points in the substrate space are the 
inputs 
> to th=
is CPPN and the output is the weight/point intensity. 
> The topology betwe=
en these inputs and the output node is evolved 
with 
> the regular NEAT me=
thod. The evolved topology and the weights are 
the 
> most important thing=
 to consider. 
> I guess this topology can change? Maybe in time (leaky neu=
rons) or 
> with recurrent connections?
> The idea of changing input topolo=
gy for the CPPN is like 
> HyperHyperNEAT :) CPPNs that further create CPPN=
s..
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "afcarl2" <a.carl@> wrote:=

> >
> > Ken,
> > 
> >    It appears that you keep attempting to recast the=
 substrate 
> inputs 
> > and outputs such that the hypercube input topolog=
y remains 
> constant. 
> > Not taking anything away from HyperNEAT's abili=
ty to exploit 
> 1d/2d/3d 
> > geometry in which the hypercube input topolo=
gy remains constant, 
> the 
> > more general question of when the hypercub=
e input topology is not 
> > constant, what do you do? Please address this =
specific issue. The 
> > answer to this question will help to identify the =

> > applicability/limitations of HyperNEAT.
> > 
> > Thanks,
> >    Andy C=
arl
> >

> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@=
> wrote:
> > >
> > > Thomas, this is a great question that highlights an im=
portant 
> area 
> > for 
> > > further research.  We can speculate on the =
right approach in 
this 
> > case 
> > > (and I have my hunches) but we won=
't know until we do some 
> > experiments 
> > > and try ideas out.
> > > 
=
> > > To give some of my thoughts, perhaps the most obvious thing is 
> > s=
imilar 
> > > to what you suggest:  Have two separate input sets, one for 
=
> > the "type A 
> > > info" and one for "type B info."  
> > > 
> > > The =
way this would look is e.g. if A was 2D and B was 2D then 
the 
> > CPPN 
>=
 > > would have 4 inputs, 2 represent A source nodes and 2 
> representing =

> > B 
> > > soource nodes.
> > > 
> > > Then, I would still have only one=
 set of outputs.  I am still a 
> > little 
> > > unclear on why you say th=
e outputs are from the second 
> substrate?  
> > In 
> > > my understandin=
g, this is still all one substrate, it's just 
that 
> > it 
> > > collects=
 inputs from two different sources.  But it can still 
> exist 
> > > with =
only one set of outputs.  So if the outputs are 2D, the 
CPPN 
> > would 
>=
 > > have 2 more inputs representing the output area for a total of 
6 
> >=
 inputs 
> > > (and one output representing the weight of a connection in t=
he 
> > > substrate).
> > > 
> > > If there was a hidden layer you could ha=
ve it exist in either 
the 
> > same 
> > > geometry as A, the same geometr=
y as B, or the same geometry as 
> the 
> > > outputs.  (For example by int=
roducing a z dimension to any of 
> > these)  
> > > Or you could have each=
 kind of hidden layer all at once.
> > > 
> > > Of course, as you note, the=
re are a lot of ways to do something 
> > like 
> > > this.  I think it wil=
l be a great issue to explore, but it may 
> > require 
> > > starting with=
 a very simple domain that isolates the issue 
(i.e. 
> > > orthogonal inpu=
t types) so we can concentrate on that rather 
than 
> > on a 
> > > specif=
ic domain with its own complications.
> > > 
> > > One other issue to note =
is that even if two sets of inputs are 
in 
> > > effect unrelated, it may =
not necessarily hurt antyhing to put 
> them 
> > in 
> > > the same geomet=
ry.  For example, they could be two separate 
> planes 
> > in 
> > > the s=
ame cube.  On the face of it, it seems like that could 
cause 
> > > proble=
ms, but we don't yet know whether the situation is that 
> > difficult 
> >=
 > to deal with in practice.  There could also be hidden 
> relationships 
=
> > > that are not obvious but still exploitable in a surprising way.
